No, in any situation you are likely to see, the kinetic energy is alway positive. As others here have pointed out, since mass is positive and the square of any real number is positive, the kinetic energy must be positive. However, Work can be negative, as when a force is used to decrease the velocity of an object (friction is an obvious example). And Work is equal to the CHANGE in kinetic energy. So the change in kinetic energy can be negative. But this just means that the object is losing kinetic energy. The kinetic energy values are still positive.

Hello. Kinetic energy is either zero or positive, never negative. This is because kinetic energy is defined as half an objects' mass multiplied by the square of its velocity. Since mass is a measure of matter, it can never be negative, and since velocity is squared, it is always positive. The kinetic energy of an object is the energy caused by an object's motion; if the object has any type of motion, it has a positive amount of kinetic energy. Unlike some other physics quantities, such as velocity, kinetic energy is not concerned with direction; it's only concerned with magnitude. Because of this, even if an object has "negative motion" by moving in a direction opposite to what's considered positive, the sign of the kinetic energy is unaffected.

Consider a particle of mass m moving with velocity v in straight line .In Classical Mechanics the Kinetic Energy of particle is given by K.E=(mv^2)/2 Since expression contains square of velocity, thus in classical mechanics kinetic energy can not be negative .Now, in Special Relativity the K.E. for a particle of proper mass m and moving with uniform velocity v in with respect to an observer is given by K.E=(Mc^2)-(mc^2) Here c is the velocity of light in vaccum and M is the relativistic mass measured by the observer and M=m/{1-(v/c)^2}^(1/2) In this case M>m as v<c and thus the K.E is non negative.

Not classically, as others have pointed out, negative kinetic energy doesn’t make too much sense. However, in Quantum mechanics particle are able to enter classically forbidden regions where their potential energy exceeds their total energy (usually called tunneling). This is only possible if the particle has negative kinetic energy inside that region. Unfortunately, particles can’t be observed in classically forbidden regions so we don’t really know what that means from an experimental standpoint.
